1.heading: Maine’s top stories of the year

content.caption: For Maine, 2015 was a year of extremes: the deepest snowfall, the biggest car crash, the longest manhunt and the fastest “hike” on the Appalachian Trail. The tragedies were severe: the sinking of El Faro, lives lost to addiction and a sad discovery in the timbers. Then there were the surreal events: a vocal restaurateur seared by national attention, dreams available for an essay and a medical miracle from a scrawled plea across a car window. While most of 2015’s top stories may never be repeated, all are sure to be remembered.

A champagne cork may weigh about one-third of an ounce, but Scott Jurek’s pop atop Mount Katahdin brought a ton of criticism down on the record-setting ultramarathoner. Jurek finished the Appalachian Trail in unprecedented time, but his bubbly celebration at the terminus led to charges and widespread criticism. The legacy of his achievement may include tighter scrutiny of AT hikers or perhaps the routing of its end away from Maine’s most fabled peak.

content.credit: Don Dunbar | Special to the BDN

content.caption: It was the winter of our discontent, Mainers. Record snowfalls in record time paralyzed travel, shuttered schools and businesses, strained budgets and tested our collective patience from Eastport to Portland. (Historic low temperatures in northern Maine also arrived in April.) But like we do every winter, we shoveled our stoic selves into spring. We don’t look back on the winter of 2014-2015 fondly, unless we’re talking about Troy R. Bennett’s snowfall anthem.

Gov. Paul LePage further redefined the role of Maine’s chief executive in 2015, which landed him at the center of controversy. He pressured opponents from jobs -- see Eves, Mark and Fitzsimmons, John -- and fired Brig. Gen. James Campbell before the general’s annual address to lawmakers. He withered the Board of Corrections, withheld voter-approved bonds (for a while) and challenged the law about vetoes (and lost in the courts). In brief, 2015 proved again why LePage is Maine’s most polarizing and arguably most powerful politician.

One day in February, a normally quiet stretch of snow-slickened highway in Carmel became the stage for perhaps Maine’s most extensive car crash. In total, some 140 vehicles spun, stuck and smashed in the whiteout conditions on Interstate 95, but miraculously no motorists were seriously injured. Once the twisted metal was hauled away and roads cleared and sanded, an investigation found that drivers largely ignored warnings to reduce speed.

This summer, all eyes were on East Millinocket and Medway, where a hard-fought campaign to garner support for a Katahdin-area national park ended in rejection. The park’s failure at the polls raised questions about its future, as without local favor -- against potent local opposition -- key political support in Washington all but evaporated. The parks’s faithful remain bullish, and efforts remain strong. But the park’s path ahead, absent a significant development, appears as rugged and tough as the wilderness sought to be protected.

The discovery of the body of Geraldine Largay, an Appalachian Trail hiker missing since 2013, in Redington Township put an end to one of Maine’s longest-running searches. How Largay, a 66-year-old Tennessean and experienced hiker, died more than a half-mile into the timbers, away from the AT, remains unknown. Given that void, there is rampant speculation, but the truth may forever remain a mystery.

The 790-foot cargo ship El Faro slipped into the sea off the Bahamas in November, a victim of Hurricane Joaquin. The captain was a Mainer, as were three others from the crew of 33. All four graduated from Maine Maritime Academy in Castine. In this era of modern shipping, when storms are tracked and all contingencies planned, the sinking of El Faro struck some as unfathomable. The investigation into its loss continues, leaving families to cope with unanswered questions and legal challenges to start their lengthy churn.

Christine Royles hoped to spark a response when she painted “Looking for someone to donate me their kidney” on the back of her Kia Soul. Against the odds, an altruistic stranger stepped forward to answer the South Portland mother’s call, an act of generosity that attracted international attention. But another kind of donation threatened to derail the transplant -- an online fundraising campaign to cover the donor’s expenses topped $50,000, prompting the hospital to delay the surgery for fear of violating federal rules against profiting from an organ donation. Royles and her donor recovered, leaving Mainers to ponder the ethics of appealing to the masses to pay off your medical bills.

As the death toll from drugs continued its relentless climb in Maine, at least two families wielded their loved ones’ obituaries as warnings against the scourge of addiction. One plainly disclosed a hard-fought battle with the disease as the cause of death, in the case of Caribou High graduate Ryan Bossie. The author of another death notice, memorializing Biddeford native Coleen Sheran Singer, boldly took numerous culprits to task, from Singer herself to Gov. Paul LePage. Bossie and Singer may be gone, but their stories reverberate as the state struggles against a drug crisis unlike any in its history.

Deep in the Piscataquis County backwoods, an alleged murderer was on the loose for most of the summer. Robert Burton dodged authorities for 68 days, a record for a Maine manhunt, until turning himself in to the sheriff Aug. 11. The family of the victim, Stephanie Ginn-Gebo, offered a reward for information about anyone who may have helped Burton. That money has not been claimed, but the total cost to taxpayers for Burton’s search is tallied at more than $500,000. Burton is expected to face trial in 2016.

It was the perfect story for the social media age: A no-nonsense Portland diner owner tells parents on vacation in Maine that their child is making too much noise and they must leave. Facebook posts are written and shared and shared. Sides are drawn, think pieces are fruitful and multiply, and the country offers its judgment. Things are quieter now, but the saga of Marcy’s Diner remains an allegory of our connected culture: A brief encounter between a restaurant owner and patrons became, for a shining moment, the talk of the nation.

In Lewiston, the nationally ranked boys soccer team earned more than a state title. The diverse Blue Devils brought pride and unity to their community amid a divisive mayoral race that was said to be a bellwether for the nation. A group of talented boys with globe-spanning heritages showed what’s possible when labels are jettisoned and the team comes first.

With the prospect of a statewide minimum wage vote looming, Portland and Bangor raised their local minimum wages in 2015. Portland, however, rejected a more significant plan to raise its local wage to $15, a decision watched across the nation. The minimum wage debate cuts to the heart of many key issues in Maine: poverty, welfare and economic stagnation. Though neither city’s wage increase has taken effect -- Portland’s will start in January, Bangor’s will come in 2017 -- the policy is proving to have political power.

For the second straight year, upheaval in Maine’s paper industry makes this list. The mill in Lincoln went bankrupt, while the remaining Verso mill in Jay will cut hundreds of jobs. After a new owner brought promise in 2014 to Old Town, this year saw those hopes dissipate yet again. Corporate restructuring and foreign investment have Maine mills operating and employing, but uncertainty reigns. Politicians are talking about energy prices and workforce investments as keys to keeping Maine’s manufacturers competitive, but progress may come too late to keep paper from the brink.

16.heading: For the right words, it’s yours

content.caption: What if your dream was only a few hundred words away? After international attention on the essay contest to find the next owner of the Center Lovell Inn, writing competitions for land, lodgings, schooners and movie theaters emerged to offer dreams for the low price of creativity and passion -- plus a small entry fee. Although there was controversy -- the police investigated Center Lovell but found no wrongdoing -- the contests became a quirky currency exchange, one in which dollars were worth little but written sentiments were invaluable.
